question: You're late again, Rick.
answer: I know, Sister, but I have a very good excuse.

question: There can be no excuse for tardiness.
answer: You're absolutely right. I should never have stopped to save that drowning infant. I'm just weak, Sister; I'm so weak.

question: All right, stop that... Children, on the bus.
answer: Sister, do you ever get lonely after vespers? If you do, why don't you give me a call. I'm in the book.

question: Get going, Rick... you're late enough as it is.
answer: Right... Think it over. If you don't all calm down I'm gonna drive this thing over a cliff. Ah... youth.

question: Okay, Timmy... hold that smile... and watch the birdie. There. We see he has his camera and backdrop set up in the camera department behind a velour curtain which blacks out the rest of the store. He's conservatively dressed in a suit, vest and tie. He looks like he could be a Young Republican. But under those Sears clothes is a man a little off center. Rick's best friend. Need we say more? He takes the film out of the camera. The matronly mother is in the process of gathering up her baby. These should be in the mail to you by next Friday. Next. Whoa. Look at those babies. How are we doing? My name is O'Neill. And you are...?
answer: Klupner. Mrs. Klupner.

question: Mrs.?
answer: I'm separated.

question: Then there is a God. Why don't we take that baby picture. If I were you, I'd breast feed until I was 17 or 18. Tell ya what... Why don't you lean into the picture with your child? A-huh. A little more... good! He gets out from behind the camera. I'm getting one heck of a glare off your dress there. Could you undo a few buttons?
answer: Of course.

question: Now lean in a little more... more... more... Hold that pose. He runs from behind the camera and poses with the woman.
answer: enters and witnesses the photo session. He immediately jumps into the shots.

question: Where'd she go?
answer: She probably had sex scheduled for 12:30. O'Neill, let's pick up the guys for a drink... I have major news to announce.

question: Okay... be right with ya.
answer: He picks up some photographs of today's work. Pictures a family will cherish forever. Hey, Chulo, where are you, man?

question: How you guys doin'... Could you believe how overcast it was this morning? Bad day for sailin', waves are too rough and...
answer: You can skip the small craft warnings. We're in a hurry.

question: No prob, bud... Here's today's dealie... We got... uh, veal... ah... veal... What's this word? Yeah right. I always want to say Paramisian when I see that. We looked at them under the jigamabob in biology once. Little squirmy, creepy things that live in your intestine and...
answer: Please... We have an appointment in a half hour...

question: Wow, sounds stressful. What do you guys do for a living? Whoa... You got to go to school for that or what?
answer: Look, forget the specials. We'll take three hamburgers.

question: God, you're a slob.
answer: But a fabulous cook.

question: What are we having?
answer: It's either meatloaf, Swiss steak or charred flesh. I won't know till it's finished.

question: I think your dinner's burning.
answer: Don't worry... it's supposed to do this.

question: Want to hear something great? Bobbie and Phoebe are throwing me a shower. It's really gonna be fun.
answer: Not as much fun as the bachelor party the guys are throwing for me.

question: You're going to have a bachelor party?
answer: Of course. I'm a traditional guy... It's a traditional event. Well, what do you think?

question: It looks awful.
answer: Yes, but looks are deceiving... Not in this case, however.

question: Are you going to have women at your party?
answer: No, sweetheart, it's a stag party. Does stay home.

question: I'm not talking about does. I'm talking about hookers.
answer: Oh, those. Why do you ask?

question: Because from what I've heard, it's a tradition and you're a traditional guy.
answer: Deb, you is my woman now. I is yo man. No painted lady ever gonna come between us. Okay, you got it. I got a way we can seal the deal -- what'd you say?

question: Cole?... Cole! Cole?
answer: Over here, Deb... in the Smokehouse. Hi, Deb. Just got back from the mountains. Isn't this a beauty?... It's gonna look great in the den.

question: Cole, we've got to talk.
answer: Finally realized Rick's a jerk, huh?

question: No, Cole, I...
answer: It's all right, I forgive you. I'm not the vengeful type. We'll forget what happened. Why don't we take a trip together? Maybe kill a few lions in Kenya over Christmas.

question: Cole, listen to me... I've got to tell you...
answer: You know, when you dumped me for that wimp, I thought, Cole, she'll be back. God wants the two of you to be together, and sure enough...

question: Cole, I'm marrying Rick.
answer: You're marrying him? Then why are you coming back to me?

question: I'm not. I just thought I should tell you myself before you heard it somewhere else.
answer: You know how that makes me feel, Deb? Wanta know how that makes me feel? Angry, Deb. Yesss, that's the word, angry. But if he makes you happy, you go right ahead. I want you to be happy, Deb. No matter what, no matter how angry it makes me, no matter how much it hurts. Be happy, Deb. Be oh, so very, very happy.

question: Cole, I'm sorry, I...
answer: That's all right, Deb. Go be happy and smile a lot, Deb. Do it for me.

question: I'm going now, Cole.
answer: I understand, Deb. 'Bye... be happy.

question: Okay, Rick, hold out your arm.
answer: You wouldn't hurt your own brother, would you? I changed my mind. I don't need a blood test. The marriage is off. I -- You always were sneaky, Stan, very sneaky.

question: Rick, marriage will be good for you. It's done wonders for me.
answer: True, you're a lot handsomer now. Don't you have enough blood already?

question: You won't miss a thing about being single... The wild parties, the different girls every night, running around like a maniac... God, I miss that.
answer: Stan, you're depressing me... Hey, I didn't know you were going to fill 'er up. Just take a couple of gallons, okay? That's an even trade... a cotton ball for all my blood.

question: Okay, Rick, all finished. I can't wait for that bachelor party... I need the action. Don't say anything to my wife about it.
answer: Hi, Tina.

question: Well, I have to admit my game's a little rusty, but I love polo. It's unrelenting, a constant challenge to the senses. Really a beautiful experience.
answer: Rick, I want to cut through the b.s.

question: I'd love that.
answer: Good. I think you're an asshole. No, let me correct that, an immature asshole. Which is fine, except you're marrying my daughter and I'm afraid my grandchildren are going to be little assholes.

question: Mr. Thomerson, I...
answer: Let me finish. Debbie's an adult. She can do what she wants. But if you want your marriage to last, you're going to have to change some things about yourself. If I may make some suggestions...

answer: First, you're a slob. You have to dress for success. Second, your outlook on life...

question: Great, Mom.
answer: If I were you, I'd worry less about the shower and more about Rick's bachelor party.

question: Ilene, why would I want to do that? I trust Rick.
answer: Of course you do. I trusted my ex, Mel, too. Cousin, I can only talk from experience. What do you think they do at these parties, have tea and play scrabble?

question: Ilene, Rick promised...
answer: Debbie, don't be naive. Men are pigs.

question: Nice shot.
answer: Thank you, sir.

answer: I've tried to change her mind.

question: It's not her mind you need to change. It's Disneyland head in there.
answer: But how can I do that?

question: If it were me, I'd reason with him first. Then, if that failed... ...I'd take more persuasive action.
answer: Thanks for the advise, sir.

question: He begins to walk toward the priest. Suddenly, out of nowhere, Cole appears at his side. Cole. Don't you know it's bad luck to see the groom before the wedding?
answer: I want Debbie.

question: Cole...
answer: You dump her and I'll give you cash.

question: What's Debbie's blue book value right now?

question: I'm marrying Debbie.

question: Thanks, Dad. Cole, go away.
answer: He's gonna hurt you, Debbie. He'll never be true to you the way I would.

question: Thank you. We'll all keep that in mind. 'Bye now.
answer: Rick, me and you aren't through yet.

question: Ladies and gentlemen, Cole Whittier. Let's hear it for him -- a funny, funny guy. We love ya, babe. You think the gods are telling me something? Huh? Wha...

question: Oh... I got something for that.
answer: Stop fooling around... I need to talk.

question: What's the matter?

question: C'mere.
answer: That feels so great.

question: Good...
answer: Um... that's very relaxing.

question: I don't want to talk about it. I love you guys. I love my friends. You want to share it?

question: Right. My marriage is the worst. All crap. A big pile of shit.
answer: Maybe your marriage should lay off grains for a while.

question: She hates me. It's over. You'll see, as soon as you get married, everything changes. You sure you want to go through with it, man?
answer: What do you mean, it changes?

question: Come on, get him on the bus. Well... twenty-four more hours to go and tonight we'll share with our friends and loved ones the joys of those last moments of singleness.
answer: You better not have too much joy.

question: Wouldn't think of it. Because tomorrow... We're going to the chapel and we're...
answer: Gonna get married... Gee, I really love you...

question: And we're gonna get ma-a-a-ried. Yeah, yeah, oh, yeah. This is it, lady. Last stop.
answer: Can't I just go with you guys?

question: Sorry, we got men's business to do. It's no place for a lady.

question: Did I promise that? I don't remember that...
answer: You're really pissing me off.

question: Okay, I promise... I swear on my mother's grave.
answer: Your mother's not dead.

question: Well, if I go back on my word, I'll kill her.
answer: Have a good time. Don't make it too late.

question: Anything you say, ma'am. Have a fun shower. Use soap.
answer: I love you.

question: So we want your best girls, the cream of your crop.
answer: Let's see your bread. Okay, I got just what you're looking for. Margot... Darlene...

question: Park View Hotel, Room 1002.
answer: They'll be up there in a half hour.

question: Hi. I must have just missed my friend. He hired you for a bachelor party.
answer: At the Park View Hotel, Room 1002. What about it.

question: Yeah. Right. This is the new address. We changed our minds and decided to send the girls over to his house instead. And here's a fifty... I want this to be a surprise, so you never saw me, okay?
answer: No problem.

question: Are any of those right?

question: Yes, you. We're looking for our room... 1002.
answer: It's on the tenth floor.

question: What do you know, they moved it. Catch you later.
answer: Keep your voices down. This is a respectable establishment. We don't go for any funny business here. Just then a GUY with a Moosehead Beer hat and TWO GUYS in a moose costume pass him and enter the elevator with the boys.

question: What do you think's gonna go on at the guys' party?

question: I mean it. The car is yours. Dump Debbie.

question: Low mileage... Handles like a dream.
answer: So does Debbie.

question: Jumbo, where the hell are the women?

question: Out.
answer: Guys, I think I'd rather stay here.

question: C'mon, Larry. Be good for you.

question: Congratulations on your daughter's wedding. Who's she marrying?
answer: A real turd.

question: The Dick.
answer: Let's get this thing going. Tray, please. Looks good. Can I have the bun, Michael? And now, Nick... or is it Mr. Dick?

question: Nick.
answer: Nick, if you would be so kind...

question: (concerned; calling What are you doing?

answer: Sorry, I can't hear you. Some pin head's yelling... Shut up, I'm talking here. Now look, I want you to go back and I don't care what you do. Stop that marriage.

question: Yes.
answer: That's a good question. From the way I understand it, according to supply side economics, when supply exceeds demand, recession is the result. That's why I think we should control the credit markets and increase the prime rate. That way, the consumer price index will stabilize and we will have economic recovery.
